text.value: He was so easily frightened, that even moving into a new house had him worried sick. To you and I, the house may look normal. But not to Freddie.
The house made peculiar noises and Freddie feared that ghosts and monsters may be hiding in the darkness.

Just before bedtime, Freddie searched the house for things to help protect him from the darkness. In his father’s toolbox, he found a torch. His father wouldn’t mind if he borrowed it. Freddie hoped that the torch would help him to feel brave during the night.

When bedtime arrived butterflies began to flutter in Freddie’s tummy. “I’m almost nine!” he thought to himself. “Thats too old be be afraid of the dark!” He really wanted to be brave but sometimes it was difficult.
His mum tried to calm him as she tucked him into bed. “Sometimes things seem scarier in the dark, but if you take a deep breath and then use the torch soon you’ll see that there is nothing to fear.”
When the lights went out, Freddie began to get scared. He began to imagine all sorts of terrifying things.
Freddie took out his torch and searched through the darkness. He didn’t see anything scary, just the contents of his very untidy bedroom. Relief swept over him and he settled back into bed.

But the Fear wouldn’t let him sleep. “There is a monster hiding underneath your bed” the Fear said. Freddie lay in the darkness and imagined a slobbering slimy creature with long tentacles lurking beneath him.

Freddie felt dizzy. His heart beat faster. He started to sweat. Freddie tried to be brave but it was too difficult.  “Let’s go downstairs where the monsters can’t find us!” said the Fear,. With that Freddie leapt out of bed and the Fear followed.

In the darkness of the hallway, Freddie glimpsed something frightening. It was gigantic, and dripped great oozing globs of slime onto the cold tile floor. “It’s a ferocious swamp creature”, the Fear insisted. Freddie's imagination ran wild. He imagined a misty swampland filled with strange insects and reptiles.
Deep Breath.
When Freddie was finally calm, he shone the torch on the monster. The  monster disappeared in a flash. All that was left was  a coat stand full of tattered and damp raincoats.
But Freddie had spoken too soon. As he stepped into the kitchen, a cold blast of air made him pause. He shivered in his pyjamas. The hair on the back of neck stood on end.
In front of his eyes, a ghostly form appeared. It danced in front of the window, pale and mysterious. The light of the moon shone through it. “It’s a ghost!
DEEP BREATH.

Freddie really wanted to call out for his mum but he was determined to be brave and face the monsters alone. He shone his father’s torch on the ghost, and hoped that it would disappear. Looking closely, Freddie saw that the ghost was covered in a strange flower pattern. It wasn't a ghost at all,  but a curtain blowing in the wind.

Freddie felt very silly indeed. He had gotten scared by monsters that weren’t even there at all. The swamp monster had just been an old coat. The ghost had been a curtain blowing in the wind. Maybe the monster under the bed wasn’t real either. After all this adventure, Freddie was exhausted. His sleepy head was longing for a fluffy pillow. Freddie began to make his way back upstairs, ignoring the Fear’s protests.
When they reached the bedroom, Freddie was determined to face his foe and discover it's true identity using his father's torch.

Freddie crawled on his belly, under the bed and into the depths of the monster’s cave. The cave was too dark and deep for even the faintest light to be seen. Freddie couldn’t help but be scared. This kind of darkness was where the Fear was the strongest. Despite his fear, Freddie kept crawling.
DUNNO WHAT TO PUT HERE.

At last, he came face to face with monster under the bed. It looked just as horrid as he'd imagined. Within an instant, it attacked. It pelted Freddie with giant dust mites until he was coughing and sneezing uncontrollably.
Freddie was lost in a cloud of dust.

In the blink of an eye, the monster had disappeared. Around him, all was still and quiet. Not a ghoul or monster in sight. In his hand, Freddie found himself wrapped up in a dusty old blanket. “So this is the true identity of the monster under the bed!” he said. Beside him stood the Fear, so tiny he could barely be seen.

The bedroom door creaked open and Freddie’s mother appeared. “I heard a racket, did something frighten you?”, she asked. “No mum,” Freddie answered. “I wasn’t afraid of anything.” So she kissed him goodnight and went back to bed.

Freddie climbed into his own bed, and lay his head upon the pillow. His father's torch lay beside him, emitting a warm, comforting glow. The Fear had disappeared and Freddie felt braver than he ever had before. Within moments, he was fast asleep.
